questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of Poland's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Poland's syndrome consists of

  • hypoplasia or complete absence of the breast. (Option A ruled out)
  • costal cartilage and rib defects, hypoplasia of the subcutaneous tissues of the chest wall, (Option C ruled out)
  • ( Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Breast hypoplasia may also be iatrogenically induced before puberty by trauma, infection, or radiation therapy.
  • Symmastiais a rare anomaly recognised as webbing between the breasts across the midline.
  • Accessory nipples (polythelia) occur in <1% of infants and may be associated with abnormalities of the urinary and cardiovascular systems.
  • Supernumerary breasts may occur in any configuration along the mammary milk line, but most frequently occur between the normal nipple location and the symphysis pubis.

questions.text: Which among the following structures doesn't relate to the posterior surface of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Functional Anatomy of the Breast :

  • The deep or posterior surface of the breast rests on the fascia of the pectoralis major, serratus anterior, and external oblique abdominal muscles, and the upper extent of the rectus sheath. (Option B, C, D Ruled Out)
  • The breast is composed of 15 to 20 lobes, which are each composed of several lobules.
  • Fibrous bands of connective tissue travel through the breast (Cooper's suspensory ligaments), insert perpendicularly into the dermis, and provide structural support.
  • The mature female breast extends from the level of the second or third rib to the inframammary fold at the sixth or seventh rib.
  • It extends transversely from the lateral border of the sternum to the anterior axillary line.
  • The retromammary bursa may be identified on the posterior aspect of the breast between the investing fascia of the breast and the fascia of the pectoralis major muscles.
  • The axillary tail of Spence extends laterally across the anterior axillary fold. The upper outer quadrant of the breast contains a greater volume of tissue than do the other quadrants. The breast has a protuberant conical form.

questions.text: Which quadrant of the breast contains the greatest amount of tissue?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Functional Anatomy

  • The upper outer quadrant of the breast contains a greater volume of tissue than do the other quadrants. The breast has a protuberant conical form.((Option A, C, D Ruled Out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The base of the cone is roughly circular, measuring 10 to 12 cm in diameter.
  • Considerable variations in the size, contour, and density of the breast are evident among individuals.
  • The nulliparous breast has a hemispheric configuration with distinct flattening above the nipple.
  • With the hormonal stimulation that accompanies pregnancy and lactation, the breast becomes larger, increasing in volume and density. In contrast with senescence, it assumes a flattened, flaccid, and more pendulous configuration, accompanied by a decrease in volume.

questions.text: Which among the following arteries doesn't supply blood to the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Arterial Blood Supply of the Breast:

The breast receives its principal blood supply from

  • internal mammary artery (Perforating branches from the internal thoracic artery)
  • Branches from the axillary artery, including the highest thoracic, lateral thoracic, and pectoral branches of the thoracoacromial artery.
  • Internal Thoracic Artery:It's a branch of the subclavian artery, and it supplies the mammary gland through its perforating branches.
  • Axillary Artery:Several branches of the axillary artery provide blood supply to the breast. These include the lateral thoracic artery, superior thoracic artery, and acromiothoracic (thoracoacromial) artery.
  • Posterior Intercostal Arteries:Lateral branches of the posterior intercostal arteries also contribute to the blood supply of the mammary gland. These arteries distribute blood to the breast primarily from its anterior surface.

Venous Drainage:

  • Superficial Veins:These veins gather and drain blood from the mammary gland toward the base of the nipple. They form an anastomotic venous circle at this point.
    • From there, the superficial veins connect to the internal thoracic vein.
    • They may also connect to the superficial veins in the lower part of the neck.
  • Deep Veins:The deep veins of the breast drain into major venous pathways.
    • They typically drain into the axillary vein.
    • Some deep veins may connect to the posterior intercostal veins.

This vascular arrangement ensures the mammary gland receives an adequate blood supply, primarily from the front (anterior surface) of the breast. The posterior surface is relatively less vascular.

questions.text: Which group of lymph nodes in the breast is classified as part of the external mammary group?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lymphatic drainage of the breast happens via

  • Axillary lymph nodes (External mammary Lymph node) (85%)
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes (15%)

Six axillary lymph node groups recognised by surgeons:

These axillary lymph node groups play a crucial role in draining lymphatic fluid from different regions of the breast and upper extremity, contributing to the overall lymphatic system's function in the chest and arm area.

questions.text: Which among the following doesn't have a profound trophic effect in the normal development and function of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A profound trophic effect in the normal development and function of the breast is due to progesterone, estrogen, and prolactin. (Option A, B & D ruled out)

  • Breast development and function are initiated by a variety of hormonal stimuli, including estrogen, progesterone, prolactin, oxytocin, thyroid hormone, cortisol, and growth hormone.
  • Estrogen initiates ductal development, whereas progesterone is responsible for differentiation of epithelium and for lobular development.
  • Prolactin is the primary hormonal stimulus for lactogenesis in late pregnancy and the postpartum period.
  • It upregulates hormone receptors and stimulates epithelial development.
  • The gonadotropins luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) regulate the release of estrogen and progesterone from the ovaries.
  • In turn, the release of LH and FSH from the basophilic cells of the anterior pituitary is regulated by the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus.
  • Positive and negative feedback effects of circulating estrogen and progesterone regulate the secretion of LH, FSH, and GnRH.
  • These hormones are responsible for the development, function, and maintenance of breast tissues.
  • In the female neonate, circulating estrogen and progesterone levels decrease after birth and remain low throughout childhood because of the sensitivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis to negative feedback from these hormones.
  • With the onset of puberty, there is a decrease in the sensitivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis to negative feedback and an increase in its sensitivity to positive feedback from estrogen.

questions.text: Which among the following hormones is responsible for lobular development of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Progesterone is primarily responsible for lobular and alveolar development of the breast, especially during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.

In the female neonate, circulating estrogen and progesterone levels decrease after birth and remain low throughout childhood because of the sensitivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis to negative feedback from these hormones.

  • With the onset of puberty, there is a decrease in the sensitivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis to negative feedback and an increase in its sensitivity to positive feedback from estrogen.
  • These physiologic events initiate an increase in GnRH, FSH, and LH secretion and ultimately an increase in estrogen and progesterone secretion by the ovaries, leading to the establishment of the menstrual cycle.
  • At the beginning of the menstrual cycle, there is an increase in the size and density of the breasts, which is followed by engorgement of the breast tissues and epithelial proliferation.
  • With the onset of menstruation, the breast engorgement subsides, and epithelial proliferation decreases.

A)

questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: What is the radiation dose used in mammography?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mammography:

  • While performing a mammography, Soft tissue radiographs are taken by placing the breast in direct contact with ultrasensitive film and exposing it to low-voltage, high-amperage x-ray.
  • The dose of radiation is approximately 1 cGy, and, therefore, mammography is a very safe investigation.
  • The sensitivity of this investigation increases with age as the breast becomes less dense.
  • In total, 5% of breast cancers are missed by population-based mammographic screening programmes; even in retrospect, such carcinomas are not apparent.
  • Thus, a normal mammogram does not exclude the presence of carcinoma.
  • Digital mammography is being introduced, which allows manipulation of the images and computer-aided diagnosis.
  • Tomo-mammography is also being assessed as a more sensitive diagnostic modality.

questions.text: What is the stage of the disease for probable benign findings of the breast according to the BIRADS classification?
In which of the following conditions of the breast disease MRI scan is not useful?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the breast is useful in a number of settings:

  • To distinguish scar from recurrence in women who have had previous breast conservation therapy for cancer (although it is less accurate within 9 months of radiotherapy because of abnormal enhancement).
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer and to assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). It is less useful in low-grade DCIS.
  • It is the best imaging modality for the breasts of women with implants.
  • As a screening tool in high-risk women (because of family history).
  • Although biopsies can be performed with MRI guidance, this is complicated by the configuration of the imaging system.
  • With improved ultrasound equipment, an MRI-detected lesion can often be found on a second-look ultrasound and biopsied using this modality.

questions.text: What is the gauge of the needle used in fine needle aspiration cytology for breast diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Needle biopsy/cytology

  • Histology can be obtained under local anaesthesia using a spring-loaded core needle biopsy device.
  • Cytology is obtained using a 21-G or 23-G needle and a 10-mL syringe with multiple passes through the lump with negative pressure in the syringe. (Options A, B, D ruled Out )
  • The aspirate is then smeared onto a slide, which is air-dried or fixed.
  • Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the least invasive technique of obtaining a cellular diagnosis and is rapid and very accurate if both the operator and cytologist are experienced.
  • However, false negatives do occur, mainly through sampling error, and invasive cancer cannot be distinguished from in situ disease.
  • A histological specimen taken by core biopsy allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis, differentiates between DCIS and invasive disease and also allows the tumour to be stained for receptor status. This is important before commencing neoadjuvant therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the triple assessment of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A triple assessment test of the breast is done in any patient who presents with a breast lump or other symptoms suspicious of carcinoma. The diagnosis should be made by a combination of clinical assessment, radiological imaging and a tissue sample taken for either cytological or histological analysis, the so-called triple assessment (Options A, B, D ruled out )

The positive predictive value (PPV) of this combination should exceed 99.9%.

questions.text: Which among the following images in the given options shows microcalcification of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microcalcification of the breast is seen in the option B image.

questions.text: What is the recommended age of a woman for annual mammography screening for breast cancer according to the American Cancer Society?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At the present time, the American Cancer Society continues to recommend annual screening mammography for women older than 40 years and suggests that this practice should continue as long as the woman is in good health.
  • Younger women with a previous breast cancer, significant family history of breast cancer, or histologic risk factors for breast cancer equal to a 20% lifetime risk are recommended for screening with MRI.
  • Although the randomised trials of screening mammography did not enrol women older than 74 years, breast cancer risk increases with age, and the sensitivity and specificity of mammography are highest in older women, whose breast tissue has usually been replaced by fat.
  • It is reasonable to continue mammographic screening in older women who are in good general health and who would be considered appropriate candidates for surgery.

questions.text: Which among the following are the two views used in the mammography of the breast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mediolateral oblique and craniocaudal are the two views used in the mammography of the breast.

  • Breast imaging detects small, nonpalpable abnormalities, evaluates clinical findings, and guides diagnostic procedures.
  • Mammography is the primary screening modality for asymptomatic women.
  • The breast is compressed between plates during mammography to reduce tissue thickness, separate structures, and improve resolution.
  • On screening mammography, two views of each breast are obtained: mediolateral oblique (MLO) and craniocaudal (CC); images are usually read later in batches.
  • Diagnostic mammography is performed for evaluation of abnormalities seen on screening or for symptomatic patients; it is interpreted immediately to allow additional views if required.
  • Magnification views help characterise calcifications, while compression views improve the detail of mass lesions.

questions.text: Which among the following levels of lymph nodes are located medially to the pectoralis minor muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Axillary lymph nodes are classified into three levels according to their anatomic relationship with the pectoralis minor muscle:

  • Level I: Located lateral to the lateral border of the pectoralis minor.
  • Level II: Located posterior to the pectoralis minor; includes Rotter's (interpectoral) nodes lying between pectoralis major and minor.
  • Level III: Located medial to the pectoralis minor; includes the apical (subclavicular) nodes. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)

Functionally, the axillary lymph nodes drain the upper extremity, back, and breast.

  • Boneti and colleagues described multiple lymphatic drainage patterns from the arm into the axilla:
    • Traditional course (just below or above the vein, or directly into the subclavian vein)
    • Sling pattern (extending well below the axilla)
    • Medial or lateral apron patterns
    • Twine pattern
  • In about 4% of cases, breast lymphatics merge with those draining the upper extremity at Level I.
